meanings.definition: The action of reforming or making changes in something, typically a social, political, or economic institution.
meanings.sent1: The community saw a reformation in their local government, bringing positive changes for all.
meanings.sent2: The reformation of the school system led to better education opportunities for students.
meanings.sent3: After the reformation of the town's rules, everyone had to wear silly hats on Tuesdays.
meanings.sent4: Her leadership brought a reformation to the company, turning it into a thriving business.
meanings.sent5: The reformation of the old building transformed it into a modern, vibrant space for gatherings.

meanings.definition: The 16th-century movement for the reform of abuses in the Roman Catholic Church ending in the establishment of the Reformed and Protestant Churches.
meanings.sent1: The reformation in the church led to the creation of new religious groups.
meanings.sent2: Many people were inspired by the reformation to seek spiritual growth in different ways.
meanings.sent3: During the reformation, the church bells started playing rock music on Sundays.
meanings.sent4: The reformation shook the foundations of the church, paving the way for diverse beliefs.
meanings.sent5: In history books, the reformation is depicted as a turning point in religious practices.
